summary: In 2017, the Albuquerque Public Schools district started offering ethnic studies electives in all of its high schools.

Austin Independent School District started to develop its ethnic studies program in 2016, offering general ethnic studies courses next year. In 2018, the Texas Board of Education approved a statewide ethnic studies course starting in the 2019-20 school year.

In 1990, Berkeley Unified School District passed a policy to make a ninth-grade ethnic studies course requirement for graduation -- the first U.S. school district to do so.

California as a state last fall made ethnic studies a graduation requirement, starting with the Class of 2030. All California public schools must start offering at least one ethnic studies course by the 2025-26 school year.
Boston Public Schools in spring 2021 passed a new graduation requirement; students in the Class of 2026 will take an ethnic studies class as a history requirement.
In 2017, the Board of Bridgeport Public Schools moved to add a graduation requirement to take an African American, Latinx, or race studies class, beginning with the class of 2022.
In 2013, Chicago Public Schools introduced a districtwide Latinx and Latin American Studies curriculum.

district: Coachella Valley Unified School District, California
summary:
In 2015, Coachella Valley Unified School District made a freshman ethnic studies course a graduation requirement, starting 2016. This made the district the eighth in California to mandate it.

California as a state last fall made ethnic studies a graduation requirement, starting with the Class of 2030. All California public schools must start offering at least one ethnic studies course by the 2025-26 school year.

In 2019, the superintendent promised to increase the number of students who participate in ethnic studies courses. Now, the district offers several culturally relevant courses, including ethnic studies.

The ethnic studies movement in California accelerated when El Rancho Unified passed a high school graduation requirement resolution in 2014.

California as a state last fall made ethnic studies a graduation requirement, starting with the Class of 2030. All California public schools must start offering at least one ethnic studies course by the 2025-26 school year.

Minneapolis schools started its Ethnic Studies initiative in 2015. Five years later, the district’s board voted to require all high school students to take ethnic studies courses, starting with the class of 2025.

Teachers in the Oakland Unified School District started developing a draft framework for ethnic studies. In 2015, the district approved to offer ethnic studies courses in all high schools by the 2018-19 school year.

California as a state last fall made ethnic studies a graduation requirement, starting with the Class of 2030. All California public schools must start offering at least one ethnic studies course by the 2025-26 school year.
The district in 2005 moved to require an African American history course for high school graduation, starting later in the same year.

In 2016, the district’s board approved a plan to offer ethnic studies courses in all high schools by 2018. At the state level, Oregon passed a bill in 2017 to require ethnic studies integration in social studies from kindergarten to high school statewide, with implementation set for 2021.
In the school year 2016 to 2017, pilot ethnic studies courses were offered in five high schools in the district.

In 2015, the district’s board approved a resolution to make ethnic studies a high school graduation requirement by fall 2019.

California as a state last fall made ethnic studies a graduation requirement, starting with the Class of 2030. All California public schools must start offering at least one ethnic studies course by the 2025-26 school year.

The district first started a ninth grade ethnic studies course in 2007, before the board passed resolutions in mid 2010s to push implementation of ethnic studies courses. In 2019, the school board voted to make ethnic studies a graduation requirement by 2022.

California as a state last fall made ethnic studies a graduation requirement, starting with the Class of 2030. All California public schools must start offering at least one ethnic studies course by the 2025-26 school year.

A group of teachers began exploring ninth-grade ethnic studies courses in 2007, started a pilot in five schools in 2008-09, and ethnic studies courses were expanded to all high schools in the 2015-16 school year. The school board last year approved ethnic studies as a graduation requirement, starting with the class of 2028.

California as a state last fall made ethnic studies a graduation requirement, starting with the Class of 2030. All California public schools must start offering at least one ethnic studies course by the 2025-26 school year.
study_summary: A 2021 study found that students who were assigned to take ethnic studies courses had long-term improvement in attendance and graduation rates. The findings showed that the graduation rate of students who took the course graduated 15.7 percentage points higher than those who didn’t.

summary: In 2017, the school board passed a resolution to begin districtwide integration of ethnic studies courses. In 2019, the district revealed a guideline to incorporate ethnic studies into math class.
In late 2021, the school board approved ethnic studies as a graduation requirement starting with the Class of 2025.

In 1998, Tucson founded the Mexican American Studies (MAS) program, which became one of the biggest ethnic studies programs in the U.S. The program was banned by an Arizona bill that passed in 2010, but it was ruled unconstitutional by a federal judge in 2017.
study_summary: In a report published in 2014, researchers found that participating in the ethnic studies classes increased the students’ probability of high school graduation by 9.5%. The students had had lower GPAs on average than peers before starting the classes.

summary: In 2007, Kailua High School in Hawaii established a ninth-grade ethnic studies course as a high school graduation requirement.

Started by a few teachers eight years ago, Holyoke’s ethnic studies courses are offered this school year in grades 7-11. At Holyoke High’s Dean campus, all freshmen take ethnic studies History, while at Holyoke High North, students choose whether to take ethnic studies (as their history class).
study_summary: A new Globe Magazine data analysis shows that ethnic studies students graduated at a higher rate than their peers, when various factors are controlled.
